passages.text: Rating Change: NEUTRAL | PO: 15.00 EUR | Price: 13.97 EUR

We have been concerned that Solaria's management was addressing too many new verticals at the same time, while progress remained limited for core solar activities. However, valuation has now well recovered and assumes execution, ramp-up, asset rotations, and/or from datacentres upside - most of which remains to be seen. Our bullbear scenario analysis shows a quasi- binary outcome at current levels. With this in mind, we downgrade to Neutral from Buy with a revised €15 PO (previously \(\) 9.50\(, see updated estimates and methodology inside).

Our analysis of Solaria's solar portfolio in Spain shows merchant revenues down - 3% to mid- August, but diversification should help. Still, execution risks remain high, with the asset base set to almost quadruple in less than 16 months and given historical delays. Whilst we acknowledge 2.5GW built, under construction or ready to build as of Q1, it still leaves close to 2GW to meet 2026 targets (including new wind and storage assets). We reflect this in our pipeline valuation discounts at 35% to 2030 and 75% thereafter (compared to a 25- 75% base in peers).

Given the relative magnitude of investments (2025- 26 capex = 100% market cap), funding can rapidly become a concern without more progress on asset rotations to contain leverage. Our base case assumes 30% pipeline sales with 30% gains, with leverage kept around 7x to 2030 but staying above 9x without asset rotation. So far, deals have been limited (€25- 40m other revenues in 2023- 24), but management has targeted €650m+ cash generation from datacentres across 2024- 28.

Management is expected to update the market on datacentre in September, with this event delayed a year and the one deal announced so far falling through. Whilst we acknowledge Solaria has more recently secured a real estate deal and new investors, multiples and upside are difficult to circle back given the lack of comparable transactions. We think the shares already price €600m upside. Our €15 PO implies 10x 2y forward EV/EBITDA excluding gains and datacentres (vs EDPR 11x at our PO, and clean energy transition master- trading on 8x).
clean energy transition master-trading on 8x).

Solaria started as a Spanish maker of solar panels in 2002, but withdrawn from manufacturing in 2014 to focus on developing and operating plants whilst still keeping an integrated profile. It currently less than 2GW of assets mostly in Spain, and aims to further build capacity towards 20GW by 2030. The company is also aiming to monetize infrastructure assets in networks and real estate. Solaria is still \(35\%\) controlled by the founding family.

Whilst Solaria's risk profile has self- help potential to improve (more PPAs + storage) we think the market is now pricing in too much execution in renewables - where more progress is needed (solar but more especially on storage with wind still remote) and/or material datacentre upside, which remains to be seen.
Price to Book Value 2.8x

We were already cautious about Solaria's more aggressive merchant profile as low power prices and negative hours in Spain persist. But progress seems to have been made, with merchant exposure now disclosed at \(25\%\) in 1Q25 from \(35\%\) at FY24. Similarly, the company seems to be progressing on construction for 2025 (based on company communication across social media) but we think the market has now either assumed: (1) execution risks have decreased significantly, which we think is unwarranted; or (2) datacentre upside can crystallize soon at good multiples, which remains to be seen, and whilst some deals are finally closing (Greneria land deal with Stonepeak, an alternative assets and infrastructure investor) no major progress on datacentre monetization (excluding the one deal with Datasection that fell through). The company will update the market on its strategy in September, and short interest – whilst still high at \(18\%\) – has been cut almost \(50\%\) recently on the back of a \(10\%\) share buyback announced, new investors buying in (Stoneshield, a real estate and datacentre investment fund, recently disclosed a \(9\% +\) stake – Solaria also sold a \(2.5\%\) stake to an undisclosed long- only investor) and expectations on datacentres build up. We think the risk- reward is now more balanced, and downgrade to Neutral with a new €15 PO (from €9.5) pricing now a \(50\%\) change of datacentre monetization (€600m).
Solar performance continues to be challenged in Spain, with merchant revenue estimates \(- 3\%\) yoy as of mid- August.

Solaria's more aggressive merchant profile (revenues used to be close to \(40\%\) of generation but are now disclosed at \(25\%\) , excluding hedging, compared to peers at around \(15 - 20\%\) , including hedging) underpinned the market strong reaction when power prices in Spain dropped significantly in early 2024 (first ever negative hours) on exceptional hydro conditions (see Exhibit 2).

We had thought concerns were overdone, as Spanish forwards recovered, but exceptional hydro persisted into 2025 and power prices took a hit again in the short term as did the share price, down more than \(- 60\%\) since end- 2022 by mid- May this year. This compares to the wider sector in Europe up \(+35\%\) (see Exhibit 1).
Exhibit 1: Solaria has underperformed the sector by 70p since 2022 Solaria vs Sector performance (total return, base 100 = 1 Jan 2023) Jan 23 to Aug 25
Exhibit 2: Solaria has largely tracked Spanish forwards since 2022 Solaria (base 100 = 1 Jan 2023) vs Spanish 1Y power forward (€/MWh) Jan 23 to Aug 23

Nevertheless, the shares rebounded and are now up \(+75\%\) since the lows of April- May, largely outperforming other European pure- play renewables names, which started to recover after US tariff announcements (and subsequent newsflow on US renewables policies - see Exhibit 3). Shares already performed well alongside Q1 results in early June and an announced \(10\%\) share buyback program "in the context of different corporate actions". We note that \(1.5\%\) have been bought up to end July - and that Solaria subsequently sold a \(2.5\%\) stake to a long- only investor, and that the company currently holds around \(1\%\) of its capital.

Exhibit 3: European renewables' recent performance has been largely dependent on US policy European renewables vs Utility sector and Clean Energy Transition index total return \((100 = 1\) Jan 2024) Jan 23 to Aug 25
Source: BofA Global Research, Bloomberg

Spanish power environment remains difficultWe remain cautious medium- term on Spanish power. We assess the incremental cannibalisation from solar assets in Spanish power markets and, therefore, incremental low to zero power price hours. We use real- time data from the European networks agency ENTSO- E and calculate Spanish "duck curves". Our forecasts from 2024 onward are based on Spain's 2030 national energy targets published in the NECP (National Energy & Climate Plans) from June 2023 and assume linear progress toward said goals. This allows us to estimate: (1) the number of hours in a given day when supply is likely to surpass demand (i.e., frequency); and (2) the extent of MWh generation oversupply to households (i.e., intensity). We forecast an increasingly deep duck curve in Spain, with 100TWh+ of oversupply by 2030 (see Exhibit 4, Exhibit 5 and Exhibit 6).
Exhibit 4: We forecast an increasingly deep duck curve in Spain by 2030 Spanish power 'duck' curves (MW) 2018-30E
Source:BofAGlobal Research estimates,ENTSO-E,various public agencies
Exhibit 5: Negative hours could cover half the day in Spain by 2030 Spanish power supply \(>\) demand (hours %) 2018-30E
Source:BofAGlobal Research estimates,ENTSO-E,various public agencies
Exhibit 6: Oversupply could grow from 3TWh in 2023 to 100TWh+ in 2030 Spanish power supply \(>\) demand (MWh) 2018-30E
Source:BofAGlobal Research estimates,ENTSO-E,various public agencies

Another way to look at this is at Spanish hours when prices were below €45/MWh, which was considered central for Spanish solar PPA prices over the past two years (with recently signed deals more in the €30- 40/MWh range we understand). This would imply hours when an operator would not meet its cost of capital. 2025 is improving from 2024 (- 23% less hours - see Exhibit 7) but remains meaningly worse than in 2023 (135% more hours). We also show the numbers of hours below €10/MWh as a measure of deeper stress on the Spanish power market, with - 24% less hours in 2025 than 2024 but still +266% more than in 2023 - see Exhibit 8).

Whilst it is not the intent of this report to go into details about recent power market trends and drivers, we note that the Spanish power market has been tighter in 2025, with power consumption up +2.3% in 1H25 and given hydro production down - 3.6% and wind production down - 32% over the same period (and with a national blackout in April).
Exhibit 7: 2024 delivered below central PPA prices for Spanish solar for over 30% of the year, 2025 slightly better so far Spanish hours below €45/MWh, 2023-25
Source: BofA Global Research estimates, ENTSO-E
Exhibit 8: 2023 saw the first ever negative hours in the Spanish power market, 2025 slightly better so far than 2024 Spanish hours below €10/MWh, 2023-25
Source: BofA Global Research estimates, ENTSO-E

We also focus this analysis on Solaria, matching its solar farms to the closest available weather stations to build more granularity on its solar radiation profile in Spain. (See this analysis in our Summertime sadness report.) Our model assumes 100% merchant for simplicity, and given the lack of granularity on PPA prices and ancillary services feeding into reported revenues and capture prices.

Nevertheless, we believe it does offer a good indication of general revenue trends for Solaria's operating assets. We estimate merchant revenues were up +30% yoy for H1 (see Exhibit 9) The company is expected to present H1 results in September/October, and we also highlight that most of the monetisation happens during the summer, when capture prices are lower (- 23% yoy in July - see Exhibit 10).

Bottom- line, we estimate merchant revenues would be down - 3% yoy this year to mid- August with capture prices lower despite lower zero- price and low- price hours overall (as capture prices account from the phasing of production during the day).
Exhibit 9: We estimate merchant revenues up \(+30\%\) yoy in H1 Solaria Spain solar merchant revenues (Em @100% MWh), 2023-25
Source: BofA Global Research estimates, Bloomberg
Exhibit 10: However, capture price are getting lower into the summer Solaria Spain solar merchant capture prices (€/MWh @100% MWh), 2023-25 for Q1-Q4 and June-Sept
Source: BofA Global Research estimates, Bloomberg
The company expects to diversify geographies and technologies, but execution risks remain as management targets almost quadrupling capacity in less than 16 months and given historical delays.

Solaria has transformed over the years from a solar panel manufacturer to a solar farm developer and operator. Having more than quadrupled assets under operation from 360MW in 2019 to 1,658MW in 2023, it aims to do the same by 2026 (see Exhibit 11 and Exhibit 12).
Exhibit 11: Solaria expects capacity to almost double in 2025 Solaria's capacity growth in 2025 (MW) as of Q4 2024
Source: Company report
Exhibit 12: Solaria expects capacity to double in 2026, or 3.7x over 2023-24 Solaria's capacity growth in 2026 (MW) as of Q4 2024
Source: Company report

Whilst Solaria has proved it can execute on projects, it has not done so at this scale, nor on time. Indeed, the company targets ramping up from 200- 250MW additions per annum in 2020- 22 and 650MW in 2023, to 1,400MW in 2025 and 3,100MW in 2026 - after no asset growth in 2024 from permitting and construction delays. In addition, we note that actual delivery of projects has lagged management's initial 2019 ambitions by \(60\%\) and even by \(30\%\) compared to 2023 ambitions (see Exhibit 13).
Exhibit 13: Management has historically under-delivered on ambitions Solaria's asset base compared to management guidance (MW) at company events (calendar) 2019-26E
Source: BofA Global Research estimates, company report

Solaria is expanding in new countries (95% of operational assets in Spain) with targeted projects in Italy (550MW+), where it has wanted to expand more significantly since 2020, and Germany (140MW+), where it started to build a pipeline in 2022.
We welcome the geographical diversification to spread risk, but good execution is still needed.

In addition, we welcome the technological diversification (wind, storage), with hybridisation ambitions further mitigating risks. Yet execution is also needed here, with wind ambitions relatively marginal in the short term (still targeted at 3GW by 2030), having been replaced by bigger storage ambitions (19GWh pipeline, with 0.5GW targeted in Spain before June 2026).

As we have argued in the past, Solaria's assets are prime candidates for hybridisation with storage (see our Recharging the appetite for renewables sector report) to fix the revenue profile, as well as facilitate pipeline monetisation.
Exhibit 14: Batteries can smooth intermittent resources, meaning better solar monetization Illustrative power market flows across 3 days (MW load)

Nevertheless, execution is unproven for now - and regulation is not particularly supportive in Spain (no clear capacity markets thus far). We acknowledge regulation is, however, moving in the right direction and the market expects (delayed) storage tenders and the (delayed) introduction of capacity markets later this year. Peers are already ramping up deployments, and so should Solaria we believe.

We find it difficult to assess the technological quality of assets (assuming lower capex could mean a stronger construction process, but also lower- quality panels or modules with shorter life or lower efficiency). However, we believe Solaria could replicate some of its solar cost leadership (originating from a legacy in manufacturing - see Exhibit 15) in storage (see Exhibit 16), assuming ongoing strong procurement in China as well as strong benefits from hybridisation (shared capex with solar farms). Management guidelines at €80k/MWh capex for storage look broadly consistent with those of Grenergy (which we consider a best- in- class developer) at \(90 - 75k/MWh\) for hybrid projects, excluding interconnection costs (assuming it has already been spent on the solar farm).
Exhibit 15: Solaria has historically guided to 30% better capex Solar capex guidance from Solaria compared to BNEF forecasts (€/W)
Source:BNEF,company report
Exhibit 16: Capex guidance -70% better benefits from hybridisation Storage capex guidance from Solaria compared to BNEF forecasts (€/Wh)
Source:BNEF,company report

Given the relative magnitude of investments (2025- 26 capex \(= 100\%\) market cap), we also note that funding can rapidly become a concern without more progress on asset rotations to contain leverage. Our base case assumes 30% pipeline sales with 30% gains, with leverage remaining high at 7x to 2030 but contained (see Exhibit 17 and Exhibit 18).

We note that deals have so far been limited (25- 40m other revenues in 2023- 24) with only limited minority stakes and pipeline sales. There is, however, some expectation that bigger deals could materialise as assets are built, or pipeline executed at bigger scale and faster pace. We expect a 30% asset rotation target to be a minimum to achieve, whilst 50% would be more conservative and help keep leverage around 5x, which will gradually become necessary as the company builds scale.

However, without asset rotation we see leverage shooting up to 10- 11x in 2026- 27 and staying above 9x to 2030. We further show leverage sensitivity to our bull- bear scenarios (see later section on valuation). Note that leverage would also benefit should Solaria manage to crystalise value in datacentres (from either proceeds, or capital gains).
Exhibit 17: Our base case assumes \(30\%\) asset rotations at \(30\%\) gains Solaria pipeline gross capex and sales proceeds (€m) 2024-30E
Source:BofA Global Research estimates,company report
Exhibit 18: Without asset rotations, leverage shoots up to \(10x+\) Solaria leverage sensitivity to our scenarios (x) 2024-30E
Source:BofA Global Research estimates,company report
Management is expected to update the market in September. However, this datacentre event has already been delayed a year, and the one datacentre deal announced so far fell through.

Solaria has indicated for some time that it intends to pivot from a solar farm developer and operator to a 'datacentre enabler'. The company expects power, grid and real estate assets to generate exceptional revenues related to the datacentre opportunity building across Spain and the rest of Europe - and was expecting €1bn of cash proceeds from infrastructure over 2024- 28, of which more than would be €650m from datacentres alone (see Exhibit 19).

Whilst management mentioned good visibility for sales in 2024 and 2025, deals have failed to materialise so far (including one cancelled datacentre deal for 40MW and up to 200MW with Datasection), meaning management already missed on the €60m cash generation from datacentre expected in 2024, and with no deal announced so far in 2025, also risk missing on the €50m cash generation expected in 2025.
OUTLOOK 2025- 2028 - Diversification will boost exponentially our cash generation on top of energy sales
Est. cash generation evolution (€mn)
Source: Company report

We do, however, acknowledge that some deals are finally closing - notably the Greneria land deal with Stonepeak, an alternative assets and infrastructure investor, or a pre- money valuation of €125m (Stonepeak in inject capital into the JV rather than buying shares outright) and €50m of expected capital gains. We also note that new investors are buying in - notably Stoneshield, a real estate and datacentre investment fund, that recently disclosed a \(9\% +\) stake - and that Solaria sold a \(2.5\%\) stake to an undisclosed long- only investor.

Whilst the Stonepeak investment rationale is more straightforward ("securing land is undoubtedly an essential role in this [energy] transition. We view land aggregation as an attractive (...) Generia's robust pipeline, coupled with Solaria's established presence in Europe, make it a perfect fit for our newly established independent land aggregation platform" as per the combined press release from the deal) we have seen no clear disclosure regarding the Stoneshield investment - but assume that this would bank on datacentre monetization given the investor profile.

We note press reports in June 2025 that Solaria had received unsolicited takeover approaches. Whilst details are lacking and no granularity has emerged since, it remains an upside risk as large investors continue to look for bargains in the renewable sector, and as - similarly to the two new investors recently building a stake - industrial and financial companies are trying to capitalise on the datacentre upside. It is also possible that the founding family - which still owns \(35\%\) of the capital - could structure a deal to take the operator private, should valuation remain depressed - as management continue to highlight non- solicited bids and an undervalued stock in earning calls.
We think the market is already pricing in execution and ramp- up in renewables, with some datacentre upside already. Our bull- bear analysis is quasi- binary and leaves us Neutral on valuation.

Our base case assumes a ramp up and some datacentreWe think that Solaria's share price, like many renewables, has depended on (among other factors) the market's conviction that the pipeline would (or would not) be realised. In other words: Solaria's share price is largely dependent on pipeline discounts. This is complicated by the expected ramp-up in capacity additions (and historical delays) the many verticals targeted by management (expansion beyond Spain, new foray into wind, hybridisation with storage) and the lack of adequate comparable transactions for the datacentre monetisation opportunity.

Our base case valuation assumes execution of current 2025/26 targets, with a shift toward more storage hereafter, normalised asset rotation to keep leverage under control, and some monetization from datacentres already. We stress these assumptions in a bull- bear scenario analysis.
Exhibit 20: Our base case ramps up renewables and price in some datacentre already Solaria pipeline and valuation assumptions sensitivity

We use our DCF valuation of operational assets, as well as our DCF- base pipeline valuation model. We explain our base and bull- bear assumptions as:

Capacity additions: Our bases assume company- targeted pipeline over 2025 and 2026 with no wind addition beyond that and a shift to storage instead. Our bear case assumes some delays in 2026 for solar, no ramp- up beyond that, a more limited ramp- up in storage, and no wind at all. Our bull case assumes a kept run- rate in solar, a faster shift to storage, and still some hybridisation in wind.

Asset rotation: Our base case assumes normalised asset rotation to fund growth, with a \(30\%\) target already representing a ramp- up in execution (as assets and pipeline execution is growing). Our bear case assumes faster rotation at lower prices to finance growth. Our bull case acknowledges a \(50\%\) asset rotation target would be healthier for the balance sheet.

Pipeline discounts: Our base case takes capacity additions under construction at full value, a \(25\%\) discount for ready- to- built assets in 2026, and \(50\%\) beyond that up to 2030, \(75\%\) afterwards. These discounts broadly represent base industry standards for pipeline execution assessments. Our bear case assumes a bigger
discount near term to reflect historical delays. Our bull case assumes better execution on 2026- 27 targets only.

- Datacentre upside: We acknowledge it is difficult to assess the upside from the datacentre monetisation and the 1.2GW of grid connection secured for datacentres by Solaria as of Q1, as no clear transaction has been disclosed – and the perimeter consider remains unclear.

- Solaria signed in September 2024 a €50-60m sale agreement (now cancelled) with ready-to-use network access, substation, and facilities (using Solaria's former solar manufacturing buildings) to host an initial 40MW datacentre (with capacity potential up to 200MW). The implied €1.25-1.5m/MW of this transaction would therefore not be a direct read-across for grid connections (in addition of no clear disclosure on the deal assets book value and thus net equity upside).

- Another way to look at it is via Iberdrola, which also revealed back in September 2024 its intention to partner with an industrial datacentre provider. Its plan expected €150-250m EBITDA for a 200MW fully operational datacentre, of which Iberdrola was to own 20% in exchange for a powered land. Assuming the \(20x+\) EV/EBITDA multiples at which global data centres trade and the €2bn+ capex required by the JV to build the datacentre, we estimate a €1.5m/MW+ equity upside for Iberdrola from the JV stake, as contributed assets (real estate, grid connection permit, substation) should have a marginal book value in comparison.
- Previous conversations with real estate and industry specialists across our conference ascribed a €1-1.5m/MW value for a fully powered datacentre shell.

Until more granularity from closed transactions can be built, we use €1m/MW equity upside as our base case (equivalent to the €1.5m/MW upside in 4- 5 years discounted back at 12% cost of equity compared to 9% for Solaria overall but with the project warranting a higher discount for development risks), acknowledging the value in readily available consumption points, with +/- €0.5/MW sensitivity. We keep a 50% discount to this upside across our scenario to account for high execution risks, but we retain 50% of value, as we think the market is already willing to price some upside and as we acknowledge the binary scenario at these levels. Our base case implies €600m equity upside from datacentres. We note Solaria had previously disclosed ambition to sell powered land or to create up to 50- 50 JVs, meaning multiples (and upside) could be different to reflect the different economics (and risk profiles).

Indeed, we think our base case is already reflected in the share price, meaning the market is already willing to price in execution and ramp- up in renewables, with €600m datacentre upside that represents \(- 40\%\) of current capitalisation.

With this in mind and a quasi- binary outcome from our bull- bear sensitivity analysis (see Exhibit 21 and Exhibit 22), we prefer to remain at Neutral with more compelling risk- reward across the rest of our coverage.
Exhibit 21: Our bull-bear analysis is quasi-binary of +/- 50% equity value compared to our base case Equity fair value pipeline and valuation assumptions sensitivity
Source: BofA Global Research estimates

Exhibit 22: Our base case is broadly priced in by the market, meaning a bull-bear scenario of -50% to +70% compared to current trading Equity fair value pipeline and valuation assumptions sensitivity vs spot
Source: BofA Global Research estimates

We do acknowledge Solaria's strong growth profile of more than 50% near- term in our base case (excluding the €50m capital gain from Greneria in 2025) to 2027E and 30% to 2030E (see Exhibit 23), which are significantly above consensus (see Exhibit 24), even excluding capital gains. However, this growth profile could be perceived as a minimum requirement for investors at this scale, especially once execution risks are factored in (we contrast with Greenergy's 50%+ near- term EBITDA growth with much better execution on projects) and should start to be rewarded only as delivery progressively materialises.
Exhibit 23: Our base case see 50% EBITDA growth near-term... Solaria EBITDA growth profile pipeline assumptions sensitivity
Source: BofA Global Research estimates, Bloomberg Note: All 2025-27 and 2025-30 CAGR are excluding the €51m Greneria capital gain in 2025. BofA GLOBAL RESEARCH
Exhibit 24: ... which is significantly above consensus Solaria EBITDA pipeline assumptions sensitivity vs consensus
Source: BofA Global Research estimates, Bloomberg

We use the below screen to plot our own estimate of net operational assets and pipeline values (blue bars) as a share of our PO (rebased to 100 at the red dotted line) and against the current share price (red dots). Taking Acciona Energia, our PO is mostly composed of operational assets (big dark blue bar) and suggests that the market overestimates said operational value and/or pipeline valuation and/or underestimates

liabilities (where we believe we have a more conservative and granular view than consensus, as we don't limit our scope to net financial debt). This supports our Underperform rating on Acciona Energia (and even more so on EDPR) – and we similarly argue that it supports our Neutral rating on Solaria, given the high share of pipeline value already priced in.

Looking at the past 10 years, renewables (and wider clean energy transition) multiples have largely corrected since the enthusiasm in 2020- 23, when ESG investment trends pushed them much higher. It is relatively difficult to assess Solaria's multiples in this context, or against the utility sector, as we believe multiples have been distorted by small numbers as well as significant perimeter changes. We think the recent gap in valuation (see Exhibit 27 and Exhibit 28) could be explained by shares moving ahead of earnings (and/or expectations of near- term datacentre monetization).

Indeed, we note large EBITDA estimate downgrades over the past year and a half (see Exhibit 30). At the onset of 2024, consensus was forecasting \(>400m\) for 2026 compared to €270m today and €340m in our current forecasts, including €95m of capital gains (not unlike Acciona Energia or EDPR, where we are 10% above consensus EBITDA in 2026E as we continue to model pipeline and asset rotations) meaning share price could already reflect better earnings. This is further supported by short interest, which had been significant since mid-2024 at \(>25\%\) but recently cut in half (see Exhibit 29).

We have updated our forecasts to include capital gains from the recent Greneria deal (expected at around €50m), benefiting our 2025 forecasts. Our long- term EBITDA is impacted by phasing in our pipeline forecasts, with gross pipeline up \(+30\%\) as we model a faster shift toward storage. Asset rotations are necessary to keep leverage under control, which remains elevate at 7x across our forecast period on an IFRS basis (net financial debt + operating leases over reported EBITDA), but we have reduced our assumed rotations to \(30\%\) (from \(50\%\) ) in our base case, awaiting better clarity and execution from management on that front, and given we now reflect the datacentre upside in valuation (which could benefit leverage from proceeds and/or capital gains).
Exhibit 31: Our forecasts now include Greneria capital gains in 2025, mid-term pipeline phasing boost EBITDA Changes in Solaria estimates (Em, %)
Source: BofA Global Research estimates

We also update our valuation framework. We now solely use our DCF- based SOTP, as the 'fair' EV/EBITDA multiple analysis is too complicated, in our view, between pipeline execution, asset rotation gains, and datacentre upside - especially given the size of the business. We have made similar changes for Grenergy in our coverage.
Our SOTP now uses a lower pipeline discount to reflect under construction assets better, lowering the overall pipeline from \(70 - 90\%\) in 2030- 30+ to \(35 - 85\%\) (with asset rotations

at 30% vs 50%, until more track record is established). We also increase our WACCs by 50- 100bps to reflect recent rates, risk premium, development risks as well as debt/equity mix. We now reflect some datacentre value, as markets are willing to price in some significant upside. This raises our fair value by \(- 60\%\) , \(- 90\%\) of which is from the datacentre value. Overall, we raise our PO to €15 from €9.5.

Our PO for Acciona Energia is derived from an equally- weighted average of a SOTP (DCF- based) and a group EV/EBITDA headline multiple, an approach that we think reflects the drivers of share prices for renewables. Our resulting PO is €17.5.

For our SOTP, our DCFs are based on regional operating assets and future growth pipeline, with \(7 - 8\%\) WACC, 200- 300bps IRR spreads, and medium- term asset sale gains of \(30\%\) (over \(50\%\) of the pipeline). We discount pipeline growth to 2030 by \(- 25\%\) and beyond by \(- 75\%\) (our base discount across our renewable coverage).

For our EV/EBITDA, we use a 8x 2026 Y+1 target multiple (vs 8.5x Y+1 median last 2 years) that reflects a mediocre backdrop for renewables as well as caution on gross deployments and asset rotations more specifically for Acciona Energia.

Upside/downside to our PO are: wind/solar load factors, power prices, renewables capex, expected project awards and value creation spreads, returns on asset rotation deals, as well as regulation, delays in construction or permitting or any other political intervention more widely in the sector.

Our PO for EDPR is derived from an equally weighted average of a SOTP (DCF- based) and a group EV/EBITDA headline multiple, an approach that we think reflects the drivers of share prices for renewables. Our resulting PO is €7.

For our SOTP, our DCFs are based on regional operating assets and future growth pipeline, with \(6 - 6.5\%\) WACC, 200- 300bps IRR spreads, and asset sale gains of \(30\%\) (over \(30\%\) of the pipeline). We discount pipeline growth to 2030 by \(- 25\%\) and beyond by \(- 75\%\) (our base discount across our renewable coverage).
For our EV/EBITDA, we use a 10x 2026 Y+1 target multiple (vs 8.2x Y+1 median last 2 years) that reflects a mediocre backdrop for renewables.

Upside/downside to our PO are wind/solar load factors, power prices, renewables capex, expected project awards and value creation spreads, returns on asset rotation deals, as well as regulation, delays in construction or permitting or any other political intervention more widely in the sector.
Our PO for Solaria is derived from a SOTP (DCF- based), an approach that we think reflects the underlying value creation potential and associated execution risks. Our resulting PO is €15.

For our SOTP, our DCFs are based on regional operating assets and future growth pipeline, with \(6.5 - 7.5\%\) WACC, 200- 300bps IRR spreads (on capex - \(30\%\) lower than sector), and asset sale gains of \(30\%\) (over \(30\%\) of the pipeline). We discount pipeline growth to 2030 by \(- 35\%\) and beyond by \(- 85\%\) (higher than our 25- 75 base discounts given execution risks). We also price in €600m of datacentre upside.

Upside/downside risks to our PO are: solar load factors, power prices, renewables capex, expected project awards and value creation spreads, returns on asset rotation deals, as well as regulation, delays in construction or permitting or any other political intervention more widely in the sector.

VOLATILITY RISK RATINGS, indicators of potential price fluctuation, are: A - Low, B - Medium and C - High. INVESTMENT RATINGS reflect the analyst's assessment of both a stock's absolute total return potential as well as its attractiveness for investment relative to other stocks within its Coverage Cluster (defined below). Our investment ratings are: 1 - Buy stocks are expected to have a total return of at least \(10\%\) and are the most attractive stocks in the coverage cluster; 2 - Neutral stocks are expected to remain flat or increase in value and are less attractive than Buy rated stocks and 3 - Underperform stocks are the least attractive stocks in a coverage cluster. An investment rating of 6 (No Rating) indicates that a stock is no longer trading on the basis of fundamentals.
